title: Newton 2L rotation - 2 wheels - pad and spokes

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A wheel of unkown mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and unknown radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> is shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The wheel has a relatively heavy rim, lightweight spokes, and a lightweight hub, such that the wheel can be approximated to have the rotational inertia <math alttext="I equals, M times R squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> of a ring. The wheel can spin freely about a fixed axle with negligible friction. Also shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is a friction pad, which can be pressed against the outer edge of the wheel’s rim while the wheel is spinning. (a) A group of students wishes to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math> between the wheel’s rim and the friction pad. Describe an experimental procedure that would allow the students to determine the value of <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be analyzed to determine <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>.

The following day the students are given a different wheel, Wheel <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The students’ assignment is to determine the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> of Wheel <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The mass of Wheel <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is not distributed uniformly, so <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> cannot be calculated from the wheel’s mass and radius. Also, there is no hub at the wheel’s center, so the wheel cannot be directly mounted to an axle and rotated about its center for a direct experimental determination of <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.To determine <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, the students are provided with a separate hub and a set of eight identical, removable spokes. The spokes can be individually attached to the inner rim of the wheel and to the hub, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> for two, four, and six spokes. Each spoke has a significant mass and rotational inertia, while the hub has negligible rotational inertia owing to its low mass and small radius.The students mount the hub on a fixed axle and also wrap a long string around the wheel. Next, they use a spring scale to pull on the string with a constant force, resulting in a constant torque of <math alttext="tau sub 0 equals, 0.50 newton meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mo>·</mo><mtext>m</mtext></math> applied to the wheel. Using a stopwatch, they measure the time <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></math> it takes the wheel, initially at rest, to rotate <math alttext="8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn></math> full rotations, and then repeat the entire procedure using different numbers of spokes. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.
